message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only Hydrops fetalis is known to be caused by viral infections during pregnancy. Nonenveloped viruses with single-stranded DNA genomes include Parvoviruses, which are known to cause Hydrops fetalis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The question describes a nonenveloped virus with a single-stranded DNA genome, which is most likely Parvovirus B19. Infection with this virus during pregnancy can cause hydrops fetalis, a condition in which fetal fluid accumulates in two or more body compartments. Chorioretinitis can be caused by Toxoplasma gondii or cytomegalovirus. Microcephaly is associated with Zika virus infection, and vesicular rash is associated with herpes simplex virus or varicella-zoster virus.

Chorioretinitis is caused by Toxoplasma gondii, microcephaly by Zika virus, and vesicular rash by herpes simplex virus.

Among the options, only congenital infection with parvovirus B19 can cause hydrops fetalis, characterized by severe anemia and generalized edema in the fetus. The virus is nonenveloped and has a single-stranded DNA genome. Chorioretinitis is caused by other infections such as toxoplasmosis, microcephaly is caused by Zika virus, and vesicular rash is caused by herpes simplex virus.
